issue.title: Thunderdome memory leak
issue.body:
When observing thunderdome for the past releases I have been observing a memory leak: https://filecoinproject.slack.com/archives/C04M8232QRW/p1696514424646659

I don't observe that on my machines, I guess the extra workload generated by the gateway either accelerate or trigger this leak. Would be nice to investigate and fix.

comment.body:
I've observed this since `.19` and not before since I wasn't looking.
You can migrate the repo back by running fs-repo-migration binary with the `-reverse` flag (need better docs on this).
Or by manually moving the old config: `mv ~/.ipfs/{config.14-to-15.bak,config} && echo 14 > ~/.ipfs/version`.

issue.title: Thunderdome memory leak
issue.body:
When observing thunderdome for the past releases I have been observing a memory leak: https://filecoinproject.slack.com/archives/C04M8232QRW/p1696514424646659

I don't observe that on my machines, I guess the extra workload generated by the gateway either accelerate or trigger this leak. Would be nice to investigate and fix.

comment.body: I also observed a memory leak in my /ipns/opensuse.zq1.de host with 6TB of data. This breaks the workflows and I would downgrade to 0.22 if I knew how to migrate the repo back.

issue.title: Peer whitelist
issue.body:
Feature Request: A way to whitelist the peers that your node can connect to. 

This would ideally work similarly to the way that IPFS-cluster has a whitelist of cluster peers that you can connect to, except at an IPFS level instead of a cluster level.

issue.title: Peer whitelist
issue.body:
Feature Request: A way to whitelist the peers that your node can connect to. 

This would ideally work similarly to the way that IPFS-cluster has a whitelist of cluster peers that you can connect to, except at an IPFS level instead of a cluster level.

comment.body: You can use resource manager for this, setting defaults values of allowed inbound connections to 0 and setting it to 1 for whitelisted peer: https://github.com/ipfs/kubo/blob/4f303d3208babbe7f5bb40a312a24d73dbf9c9dd/docs/libp2p-resource-management.md#user-supplied-override-limits

issue.title: plugin: Add support for content blocking directly in Kubo
issue.body:
Fixes #8492.

This introduces "nopfs" as a preloaded plugin into Kubo.

It automatically make Kubo watch *.deny files found in:

- `/etc/ipfs/denylists`
- `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/ipfs/denylists`
- `$IPFS_PATH/denylists`

(files need to be present before starting in order to be watched).

Debug logging can be enabled with `GOLOG_LOG_LEVEL="nopfs=debug"`.

All blocks are logged to "nopfs-blocks", so logging requests for blocked content can be achieved with
`GOLOG_LOG_LEVEL="nopfs-blocks=warn"`:

```
WARN (...) QmRFniDxwxoG2n4AcnGhRdjqDjCM5YeUcBE75K8WXmioH3: blocked (test.deny:9)
```

Interactive/gateway users will also receive errors as responses but with less details:

```
Error: /ipfs/QmQvjk82hPkSaZsyJ8vNER5cmzKW7HyGX5XVusK7EAenCN is blocked and cannot be provided
```

One particularity to keep in mind is that GetMany() will silently drop blocked blocks from the response (warnings are logged). AddMany() will act similarly and avoid adding blocked blocks.

The code implementing all this is actually in nopfs:

- https://github.com/ipfs-shipyard/nopfs (main library)
- https://github.com/ipfs-shipyard/nopfs/tree/master/ipfs (wrappers)

The interpretation of the list rules and block detection is well tested, but a general review might be in order.

### TODO

- [ ] merge and release https://github.com/ipfs-shipyard/nopfs/pull/25
- [x] add basic CLI regression tests (`test/cli/content_blocking_test.go`)
- [x] add basic Gateway regression tests (`test/cli/content_blocking_test.go`)
- [x] dry tests so we define testCases and commands as lists and run matrix
  - [x] make `dag export` accept CID _or_ Path like all other commands
- [x] include special edge case tests for subdomain gateway
- [ ] resolve remaining TODO from `test/cli/content_blocking_test.go`
  - [ ] when blocked, HTTP error code is 500, should be 410 (may require boxo/gateway change)
  - [ ] blocking rule `/ipfs/cid/*` does not seem to block `/ipfs/cid/file`

comment.body:
Close, but not ready yet: content blocking is not applied to "no fetch" gateways.

https://github.com/ipfs/kubo/pull/10161/commits/c99068e3a7bf0f77d657fdc7897182d1aa796565 adds missing tests for "no fetch" gateways one can expose. In both cases the offline mode is done by passing custom  blockservice/exchange into path resolver, which means global path resolver that has nopfs intercept is not used,  and the content blocking does not happen on these gateways.

Needs to be fixed before merge, but at least now we have tests that fail  on this PR to surface the problem.

I'll look into this on Friday, but if I run out of time, this might slip from 0.24 to 0.25.

commits.message:
test: Gateway.NoFetch and GatewayOverLibp2p

adds missing tests for "no fetch" gateways one can expose,
in both cases the offline mode is done by passing custom
blockservice/exchange into path resolver, which means
global path resolver that has nopfs intercept is not used,
and the content blocking does not happen on these gateways.

needs to be fixed, but at least now we have tests that
fail until it is fixed.

test: double-hash Path block (blake3-multihash)

this ensures we test something other than default sha256

Ref. https://github.com/ipfs-shipyard/nopfs/pull/28
docs: remove OpenSSL section from README (#10186)

pull_request.title: remove OpenSSL section from README
pull_request.body: I believe that this was using the OpenSSL "feature" of go-libp2p, which we removed a couple of releases ago. I couldn't find any `openssl` build tag in Kubo nor in Boxo, but I haven't checked any other dependencies than that.

issue.title: plugin: Add support for content blocking directly in Kubo
issue.body:
Fixes #8492.

This introduces "nopfs" as a preloaded plugin into Kubo.

It automatically make Kubo watch *.deny files found in:

- `/etc/ipfs/denylists`
- `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/ipfs/denylists`
- `$IPFS_PATH/denylists`

(files need to be present before starting in order to be watched).

Debug logging can be enabled with `GOLOG_LOG_LEVEL="nopfs=debug"`.

All blocks are logged to "nopfs-blocks", so logging requests for blocked content can be achieved with
`GOLOG_LOG_LEVEL="nopfs-blocks=warn"`:

```

```

Interactive/gateway users will also receive errors as responses but with less details:

```
Error: /ipfs/QmQvjk82hPkSaZsyJ8vNER5cmzKW7HyGX5XVusK7EAenCN is blocked and cannot be provided
```

One particularity to keep in mind is that GetMany() will silently drop blocked blocks from the response (warnings are logged). AddMany() will act similarly and avoid adding blocked blocks.

The code implementing all this is actually in nopfs:

- https://github.com/ipfs-shipyard/nopfs (main library)
- https://github.com/ipfs-shipyard/nopfs/tree/master/ipfs (wrappers)

The interpretation of the list rules and block detection is well tested, but a general review might be in order.

### TODO

- [ ] merge and release https://github.com/ipfs-shipyard/nopfs/pull/25
- [x] add basic CLI regression tests (`test/cli/content_blocking_test.go`)
- [x] add basic Gateway regression tests (`test/cli/content_blocking_test.go`)

comment.body: @lidel I updated nopfs to a commit that has both https://github.com/ipfs-shipyard/nopfs/pull/28 and https://github.com/ipfs-shipyard/nopfs/pull/27 merged. Eventually we should produce tags for boxo, nopfs and bubble that.

commits.message: gateway: NoFetchGateway should use resolver with offline-blockservice fetcher

comment.body:
in the libp2pGatewayOption I don't see an issue.

In the other one I see it... we should create the resolver using the fetcher that uses the offline blockservice. I'll make that change.

pull_request.title: remove OpenSSL section from README
pull_request.body: I believe that this was using the OpenSSL "feature" of go-libp2p, which we removed a couple of releases ago. I couldn't find any `openssl` build tag in Kubo nor in Boxo, but I haven't checked any other dependencies than that.
